title: Protocol to assess the antitumor efficacy of an immunotherapeutic peptide in syngeneic orthotopic glioma mouse models
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Install an implantable guide screw into the mouse skull
Timing: 20 min/mouse
This step describes how to anesthetize mice and install an implantable guide screw into the mouse skull.
Note: For more details about an implantable guide screw system, please refer to the reference by Lal et al.5[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]
Prepare a heating pad to place mice after anesthesia.
Weigh the mice and anesthetize them via intraperitoneal (i.p.) injection with the dose of 100 μL/20 g bodyweight of anesthesia mix.
Note: The dose applied would lead to anesthetizing mice for 40∼60 min. C57BL/6 mice of age 4∼6 weeks are usually around 20 g of body weight, and it is OK to apply 100 μL of anesthesia mix when the mouse body weight is 20 ± 1 g.
Place the anesthetized mice on the heating pad, and apply ophthalmic ointment to both eyes of the mice.
Note: Ophthalmic ointment should be applied to mice for anesthesia longer than 5 min. Missing this step may result in mice being blind since the mouse's eyes remain open under anesthesia.
Locate the point of the skull to install a guide screw.
Take an anesthetized mouse to put on an operating table, and let the operational light focus on the mouse head.
Sterilize the mouse head with an alcohol swab and betadine.
Use a Lance blade to make an incision in the center of the mouse skull vertically between the ears and reveal the midlines.
Find the bregma of the skull (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2375-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. The position of the guide screw on the skull
The guide screw locates 2.5 mm on the right and 1.5 mm up from the bregma on the skull.

Note: It may have blood when making the incision, making it hard to find the bregma. Use a cotton swab to remove the blood and let the skull dry for a while, making the bregma easier to find.
Use a ruler to locate 2.5 mm to the right and 1.5 mm up, and make a point marker using a fine-tip Sharpie pen.
Install the guide screw into the skull.
Drill a hole on the point marker with a small hand-controlled drill that is 1 mm in diameter.
Place a guide screw in the hole and rotate it until the guide screw is tight in the skull.
Critical: It is crucial to make a proper size of the hole in the skull. A large hole leads to loosening an installed guide screw in the mouse skull. A 21-gauge needle or forceps with a similar diameter can be used to hold the guide screw and to gently squeeze into the hole (Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]).
Seal the incision by using a surgical suture.
Alternatives: A clip can seal the incision with an autoclip (stapler); however, the clip needs to be removed by a stapler remover one week later.
Conduct intraperitoneal injection (IP) injection of pain killer Meloxicam solution with 5 mg/kg dose (i.e., inject 200 μL of 0.5 mg/mL meloxicam solution into a mouse with a body weight of 20 g).
Place the mouse back on the heating pad until it wakes up.
Check the breathing of the mouse.
Reflex mouse routinely.

Methods video S1. Demonstration of guide screw installation and intracranial implantation in mice, related to “Step-by-step method details” step 5 and step 11

The movie illustrates the procedure of preparation and manipulation of how to install a guide screw into the mouse skull and conduct intracranial implantation of cells into the mouse cortex using the lab-customized stereotaxic frame with the syringe pump for 10 mice at one time.
Intracranial implantation of QPP7 cells into mice
Timing: ∼1–2 h/10 mice
This step describes how to perform intracranial implantation of tumor cell lines (e.g., QPP7 cells) into mice.
Anesthetize the mice as described in steps #1-#3.
Draw xenograft cells into Hamilton syringes.
Wash each syringe 10 times in each solution in the following order: 100% ethanol, 70% ethanol, and sterile DPBS.
Critical: It is important not to introduce bubbles into the syringe when drawing the cells. Gently and slowly wash the syringe with 100% ethanol, which will eliminate bubbles in the syringe.
Take the cells from the ice and gently flick the tube to mix the cells.
Prepare 10 syringes by gently withdrawing about 7 μL of cells in solution into each one.
Put the syringes on the injector frame and make the plunger underneath the driver of the infusion pump.
Control the pump to push the driver, ensure each syringe has a little liquid coming out, and all the plungers touch the driver well.
Intracranial implantation of tumor cells into 10 mice using the screw-guide stereotactic frame (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3] and Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2375-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Intracranial implantation using the lab-customized screw-guide stereotaxic surgery platform
Set-up of the intracranial implantation of 10 mice via the screw-guide stereotaxic frame with a syringe pump. The tumor cell line QPP7 of 1×105 cells in 5 μL DPBS were intracranially injected into each anesthetized C57BL/6 mouse.
Take an anesthetized mouse to put on an operating table, and let the operating light focus on the mouse head.

Sterilize the mouse head with an alcohol swab and betadine.
Use a Lance blade to make a small incision to expose the guide screw.
Move the mouse under the rack/clamp on the stereotactic frame.
Make the needle of the Hamilton syringe into the guide screw hole.
Make the plastic sleeve on the needle contact the skull tightly using forceps.
Alternatives: Experienced researchers can avoid creating an additional incision by following the steps.
Use a Hamilton syringe needle with a plastic sleeve (or cuff) to find the guide screw under the head skin and pierce it.
Put the needle of a syringe with pre-loaded tumor cells into the guide screw.
Carefully move the mouse together with the syringe and assembly into the stereotactic frame.
Put a small piece of cotton under the mouse head to stabilize the mouse syringe set-up if needed.
Note: Do not put too much cotton under the mouse's head since it may block the mouse's breathing. Ensure the syringe plunger touches the injector pump driver well.
Repeat steps a-d until all the mice are set up in the stereotactic frame.
Note: The number of mice for intracranial implantation depends upon the channel number of the injector. However, it is recommended not to perform more than 12 mice each time.
Intracranial injection of 5 μL tumor cells by setting the pump with a speed of 0.5 μL/min.
After the intracranial injection is finished, leave the needle in the guide screw for 10 min.
Critical: It is important to leave the needle in the mouse brain for a while to let the cells stabilize in the brain and prevent them from coming out. Gently press the mouse head to make the needle move out a little every three min.

Wash each syringe 10 times with sterile DPBS. If no additional intracranial injection is performed, wash 10 times in each solution in the following order: 70% ethanol and 100% ethanol.
Note: Immediately wash the syringe after each intracranial injection to prevent blocking in the needle.
Apply pain killer (Meloxicam solution) to mice and wait for them to wake up, as described in steps #7 - #8.
Intracranial delivery of the peptide for the treatment
Timing: ∼1–2 h/10 mice
This step describes how to treat mouse glioblastoma by directly delivering the peptide to brain tumors using an implantable guide screw system.
Prepare anesthetized mice and syringes with 20 μM peptides dissolved in sterilized DPBS as described in steps #9-#10.
Intracranial injection of 5 μL peptides as described in step #11.
Apply pain killer (Meloxicam solution) to mice and wait for them to wake up, as described in steps #7 - #8.
Examine tumor size with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
Timing: 20 min/mouse
This step describes how to examine tumor growth and the size of xenograft tumors by MRI.
Anaesthetize mice by inhalation with isoflurane.
Put a mouse in a clear plexiglass anesthesia induction box that allowed unimpeded visual monitoring of the animal.
Set 3% isoflurane mixed with oxygen in the induction box for a few min until the mouse achieves the anesthesia plane.
Note: The depth of anesthesia of the mouse can be checked by toe reflex and respiration rate.
Acquire an MRI imaging of each mouse.
Transfer the mouse to the animal bed for imaging. Monitor the mouse’s respiration by using a pneumatic sensor between the animal bed and the mouse’s abdomen, and maintain the animal’s temperature at 37°C.
Put a nose cone with 1∼2% isoflurane in oxygen to maintain anesthesia.

Scan the mouse with an MRI spectrometer with proper parameters.
Place the mouse back in the animal cage and monitor the mouse until it wakes up.
Note: The time to check the tumor by MRI after intracranial implantation varies in different glioblastoma lines. For QPP7 cells, it usually takes about one month to form a tumor in the mouse brain; hence, it is recommended to start MRI in the third week after the intracranial implantation.
Determine the tumor size by MRI images.
Open the MRI image in ITK-SNAP (v.3.8.0).
Go through each layer and find the largest tumor layer. In the software (e.g., Mac OS), go to Tools > Image Contrast > Contrast Adjustment. In the pop-up window, drag the circle in the “index into the color map” to make the tumor has good contrast with its around the tissue in the image.
Note: We usually get 11∼13 scanning image layers, and 5∼8 layers often have the biggest tumor intersection.
Go back to the main window of ITK-SNAP, choose the brush in the Main Toolbar on the left, and choose the proper size in the Brush Size drop-box.
Note: Beginning with a bush size of 5 is a good start.
Use the brush to paint and cover the tumor in each layer that has the tumor.
Note: Try to cover the tumor part with brush painting accurately. Do not over-painting or leave some part of the tumor unpainted since the software will determine the tumor size based on the painting of each layer.
Once finishing painting the tumor in each layer, go to Segmentation > Volumes and Statistics. The software will calculate the tumor size.
Sample collection after peptide treatment
Timing: ∼15–20 min/mouse
This step describes how to collect mouse serum, spleen, and brain.

Note: When the mouse appears with phenomena of brain tumor (e.g., hunchback, irritability, trembling, and apastia), cease the animal for collecting samples.
Cease the mouse by CO2.
Place the mouse with the cage or directly into a clear plexiglass box that connects to a CO2 tank or pipeline.
Turn on the valve of CO2 to cease the mouse.
Once the mouse stops breathing, remove it from the plexiglass box.
Stabilize the mouse as its abdomen upwards by pinning its four claws on a polyform.
Collect blood from mouse heart (Cardiac blood collection) (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2375-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Cardiac blood collection
The mouse was euthanized with CO2. The blood was collected immediately using a 1-mL syringe with a 26G ×1/2 inches needle.
Spray the skin with 70% ethanol to disinfect, and use a scissor to dissect the skin along the ventral midline.
Extend the dissection and gently open the skin without entering the peritoneal cavity.
Use the needle with a 1 mL syringe to puncture the thoracic cavity a little right of the ventral midline.
Withdraw the syringe plunger a little and slightly move the needle until the mouse blood enters the syringe.
Hold and stabilize the syringe, and withdraw the plunger until no more blood can be picked up.
Push the plunger to let the blood into an EDTA-coated 1.5-mL centrifuge tube.
Note: The mouse must be anesthetized or euthanized immediately prior to blood collection. The blood can be set in the 1.5-mL centrifuge tube at 25°C for about 30 min until all other samples are collected. Do not disturb the tube.
Centrifuge the tube at 2000× g for 20 min at 4°C.
Transfer the upper layer of the serum to a clean 1.5-mL centrifuge tube and store at −80°C.
Perfuse the mouse (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2375-Fig5.jpg

Figure 5. Perfusion of the mouse
(A) Creation of a perfusion solution outlet by cutting the mouse liver.
(B) Conduction of the perfusion by a hypodermic needle filled with DPBS.
Use a scissor to open the peritoneal and thoracic cavities.
Find the liver in the peritoneal cavity, and use a scissor to make a cut in the liver.
Find the heart in the thoracic cavity and gently hold it in place with forceps.
Take a DPBS-filled 30 mL syringe with an infusion needle attached.
Alternatives: If the samples will be only used for immunohistochemistry, it is recommended to use 4% of PFA instead of DPBS to perform perfusion.
Insert the needle into the left side of the heart.
Push the syringe plunger to perfuse the heart with 20 mL of DPBS.
Note: If perfusion is successful, the DPBS will come out from the incision in the liver, and it will gradually turn light brown. If the liver remains dark red, try perfusing again with additional DPBS.
Collect spleen.
Reflect the liver craniodorsally and find the spleen on the right side of the abdomen, inferior to the stomach.
Remove the spleen with forceps and scissors.
Place the spleen in DPBS in one well of a 6-well plate at 25°C.
Alternatives: If the sample is perfused with 4% PFA, place the sample in a 15-mL conical tube with 4% PFA for about 12 h at 25°C, then switch to 20% sucrose for another day at 4°C before embedding into paraffin or OCT block.
Collect brain.
Decapitate the mouse using scissors.
Gently pull and remove the mouse head skin and fur with scissors.
Keep the scissors toward the outside of the skull and carefully cut up the brainstem along the midline of the skull.

Note: Try not to cut the brain when using scissors to cut the skull.
Blunt dissection of the skull by using hemostatic forceps.
Gently insert the hemostatic forceps underneath the brain and remove the brain from the skull. Compared to the normal mouse brain, the brain with tumors shows hemorrhage on the cortical surface and swelling (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2375-Fig6.jpg
Figure 6. Comparison of normal mouse brain vs. brain with tumors
(A) A normal mouse brain.
(B) A mouse brain with tumors. The tumors grew in the cerebral cortex of the brain and emerged in the olfactory bulbs; the brain shows hemorrhage on the cortical surface and swelling.
Place the brain in DPBS in one well of a 6-well plate at 25°C.
Alternatives: If the sample is perfused with 4% PFA, place the sample in a 15-mL conical tube with 4% PFA for about 12 h at 25°C, then switch to 20% sucrose for another day at 4°C before embedding into paraffin or OCT block.
Mouse brain and spleen processing and staining for flow cytometry analyses
Timing: ∼8–10 h
This step describes how to isolate the mouse brain and spleen and then analyze the cell populations by flow cytometry.
Process brain.
Place the brain on the lid of the 6-well plate.
Use a carbon blade and scissors to isolate the tumor region of the brain.
Transfer the tumor back to the 6-well plate well containing DPBS, and use scissors to cut the tumor into 1 mm slices.
Note: Do not mash up or mince the tumor since this will reduce cell viability.
Use a P1000 pipettor with a slightly cut tip to transfer the tumor tissue into a 15-mL conical tube. Rinse the well with DPBS and transfer all residues of tumor tissue to the same 15-mL conical tube.

Centrifuge the tube at 400 × g for 5 min at 25°C, and discard the supernatant.
Add 2 mL of Collagenase IV cocktail to the tumor tissue, and use a P1000 pipettor with a slightly cut tip to pipette the tumor tissue slurry up and down 15∼30 times.
Note: Slowly pipette up and down the tumor slurry to ensure no tissue gets stuck in the pipette tip and then suck it up into the barrel.
Incubate the tumor tissues in a Biometra OV5 Duo-Therm Hybridization Oven Incubator by rotating the conical tube bottom-to-top for 15 min at 37°C.
Note: One can start to process the spleen by following step #24 while the brain tumor sample is incubating.
Check for tumor dissociation by gently pipetting up and down 30 times with a P1000 with a slightly cut tip and then 20∼30 times with a P1000 uncut tip.
Note: Usually, 15 min of incubation with Collagenase IV cocktail followed by pipetting up and down is enough for the tumor tissues to be dissociated into single cells. If tissue dissociation remains incomplete, repeat step g one or two times with additional 15-min incubation until the tumor fragments can fit through an uncut P1000 tip.
Add 8 mL of ice-cold DPBS into the conical tube to make the total volume 10 mL, and gently flip the tube to mix the tumor cells.
Filter the suspension through a 70-μm cell strainer into a new 15-mL conical tube, and rinse the strainer twice with 1 mL of ice-cold DPBS each time.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C, and discard the supernatant.
Lyse the red blood cells by resuspending the cell pellet with 2 mL of ACK Lysing Buffer.

Note: Place the conical tube at 25°C for 1∼2 min, and swirl the tube several times every 30 s.
Add 8 mL of ice-cold DPBS into the conical tube and gently flip the tube to mix the tumor cells to quench the lysis.
Aliquot 10 μL of the suspension into a 1.5-mL centrifuge tube for cell counting.
Note: It is recommended to use auto-counting equipment to count cells at this step if multiple samples are processed.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C, discard the supernatant and remove any liquid residue.
Pause point: The cells can be placed into Bambanker Cell Freezing Medium and stored in liquid nitrogen for up to 2 months before staining.
Resuspend tumor cells in the appropriate volume of ice-cold FACS Buffer and plate 2∼3 × 106 tumor cells in each well of a 96-well round bottom polypropylene plate on ice. Bring the final volume in each well to 100 μL with ice-cold FACS buffer.
Process spleen.
Place a 40-μm cell strainer in the 6-well plate well containing DPBS at 25°C, and transfer the spleen to the strainer.
Use the end of a 1-mL syringe plunger to macerate the spleen. Once the majority of the spleen tissue has filtered through the cell strainer, rinse the end of the syringe plunger and strainer with DPBS. Discard the strainer.
Transfer the dissociated spleen cells to a 15-mL conical tube. Rinse the 6-well plate well with DPBS and transfer it to the same conical tube. Add additional DPBS to make the volume up to 10 mL in total.
Centrifuge the spleen cells at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C. Discard the supernatant and remove any liquid residue.
Lyse the red blood cells by following step #25 l-m.

Centrifuge the cell suspension at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C, and discard the supernatant.
Note: Spleen contains more red cells than the brain, and it may need to repeat this step one more time to get rid of all red cells.
Aliquot 10 μL of the suspension into a 1.5-mL centrifuge tube for cell counting.
Note: It is recommended to use auto-counting equipment to count cells at this step if multiple samples are processed.
Centrifuge the cell suspension at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C, discard the supernatant and remove any liquid residue.
Pause point: The cells can be placed into Bambanker Cell Freezing Medium and stored in liquid nitrogen for up to 2 months before staining.
Resuspend tumor cells in the appropriate volume of ice-cold FACS Buffer and plate 1 × 105 tumor cells in each well of a 96-well round bottom polypropylene plate on ice. Bring the final volume in each well to 100 μL with ice-cold FACS buffer.
Incubate cells with Fc block.
Incubate cells with TruStain fcXTM at 1.0 μg per 2∼3 × 106 brain tumor cells (i.e., 2 μL of 0.5 μg/μL TruStain fcXTM stock per well) and 1.0 μg per 1 × 105 spleen cells in 100 μL for 10 min on ice.
Add the correct volume of antibody panel cocktail to its corresponding well on the plate. Mix thoroughly by gently pipetting up and down 3 times.
Note: Do not introduce bubbles when mixing the cells after adding the antibody cocktail.
Extracellular staining with antibody cocktail.
Add the correct volume of antibody panel cocktail to its corresponding well on the plate. Mix thoroughly by gently pipetting up and down 3 times.

Incubate the plate at 4°C for 30 min, and avoid light by covering the plate with aluminum foil.
Centrifuge the plate at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C, and discard the supernatants.
Wash the cell pellets twice with 200 μL of ice-cold FACS Buffer per well.
Note: If only extracellular staining is performed, directly go to step #28.
Intracellular staining with antibody cocktail.
Prepare fresh 1× True Nuclear Fix Concentrate by diluting True Nuclear 4× Fix Concentrate with True Nuclear Fix Diluent.
Add 200 μL of True Nuclear 1× Fix Concentrate to each well. Mix thoroughly by gently pipetting up and down 3∼5 times with a multi-channel P200 pipettor.
Incubate at 25°C for 1 h and avoid light.
Centrifuge the plate at 400 × g for 5 min at 25°C, and discard the supernatants.
Pause point: Cells resuspended with 200 μL/well of Cyto-Last Buffer can be stored at 4°C for 12∼18 h protected from light. Use plastic wrap to cover the plate to avoid buffer evaporation.
Prepare fresh True Nuclear 1× Perm Buffer by diluting True Nuclear 10× Perm Buffer with distilled water.
Resuspend the fixed cell pellets in 200 μL of True Nuclear 1× Perm Buffer.
Centrifuge the plate at 400 × g for 5 min at 25°C, and discard the supernatants.
Repeat steps f-g one more time.
Resuspend the cell pellets in 100 μL of True Nuclear 1× Perm Buffer.
Add the correct volume of antibody panel cocktail to its corresponding well on the plate. Mix thoroughly by gently pipetting up and down 3 times.
Note: Do not introduce bubbles when mixing the cells after adding the antibody cocktail.
Incubate the plate at 25°C for 30 min, and avoid light by covering the plate with aluminum foil.

Centrifuge the plate at 400 × g for 5 min at 25°C, and discard the supernatants.
Add 200 μL of True Nuclear 1× Perm Buffer to each well and mix gently and thoroughly.
Centrifuge the plate at 400 × g for 5 min at 25°C, and discard the supernatants.
Repeat steps m-n one more time.
Fix the cells (optional).
Pause point: This step is for extracellular staining only. This step is unnecessary if the cytometry analysis is performed on the same day.
Resuspend the cell pellets with 200 μL of Fixation Buffer.
Incubate the plate for 20 min at 25°C and avoid light.
Centrifuge the plate at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C, and discard the supernatants.
Resuspend the cell pellets in 200 μL of Cyto-Last Buffer.
Pause point: Fixed cells can be stored at 4°C and avoid light for up to 3 days before going to cytometry analysis.
Transfer cells to flow cytometry tubes and store samples at 4°C with plastic wrap to protect them from buffer evaporation in the dark until ready to analyze by flow cytometry.
